Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Admissions Policies at Women's Colleges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the last few decades, many women's colleges have adopted admissions policies extending the opportunity for enrollment to more diverse groups of students. As such, women's colleges offer an important case to study diversity inclusion policies because these institutions must still rely on some form of exclusion criteria in order to remain a women's college. Yet, sociological research has overlooked examining the experiences of students within these institutions as such policies are implemented. This study asks how academic and social experiences of diverse students are shaped by more inclusive policies. Because college achievement, persistence, and student well-being in higher education remain unequal, this research will help policy makers within educational institutions as well as those with oversight responsibility to improve policies that contribute to positive educational outcomes. The findings will inform conversations regarding college admissions policies for students, with implications for studies of social opportunity and career prospects of students in the United States today.

This project employs a year-long comparative ethnography of admissions policies at two women's colleges. They are geographically proximate to one another, have similar levels of student enrollment and were both founded in the late 19th century. Yet one has a reputation for more inclusivity and one has a reputation for less inclusivity in terms of admissions policies. This project will use three types of ethnographic methods. It will analyze over 30 years of archival records relevant to admissions to set the context for contemporary observations. The project also includes 9 months of participant observation and interviews with 120 diverse students, alumni, and employees at the two colleges to examine day-to-day institutional practices and conversations relevant to admissions. These data will be coded and analyzed with the use of qualitative coding software, Nvivo, followed by open and axial coding to detect themes in the data. Findings from this project will inform sociological theories regarding diverse participation in organizations, as well as theories related to educational diversity and social mobility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 2013, over half of single-sex colleges in the US have adopted formal policies that outline the varying criteria that determine an applicant's eligibility to apply to these colleges. In particular, these criteria outline the varying legal, biological, and social markers of sex and gender, in effect defining what constitutes "womanhood" or "manhood" within the women's and men's college context. While these policies at first glance appear to be common sense, the intention and purpose of their creation was actually to expand admission to be inclusive of transgender applicants. Because the notion of transgender challenges the biological and binary falsities of sex/gender, these new criteria thus expand the presence of these colleges from single-sex to gender-diverse and inclusive.

The purpose of this study was to examine transgender students’ experiences at two women’s colleges with transgender admissions policies. The ethnographic fieldwork of this study, funded by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, included 9 months of participant observation of campus spaces and events; 126 in-depth interviews with students, alumni, faculty, and staff; and archival research. Researchers used women's colleges as a unique case study because, while over 1000 colleges and universities have adopted gender and expression language within non-discrimination policies to protect transgender students, women’s colleges, in particular, must still rely on some form of exclusion criteria in order to remain a single-sex or women’s college. As such, we contribute to previous gender and education concerns by theorizing the relationship between organizational structure, policy, and practice and how that structures student experiences and outcomes, particularly centering students outside of the gender binary. 

Findings from this research show how seemingly inclusive diversity policies may and do continue to perpetuate unintended inequities for underrepresented and marginalized students, particularly low-income, non-white, and trans masculine students. Using an intersectional analysis, observations indicated that such inequalities arose because admission policies failed to make fundamental structural changes in how gendered power, resources, and opportunities are distributed on campus for the most vulnerable of transgender students. For instance, while the physical and symbolic gates of the institution are open to transgender students, without access to fundamental resources such as adequate health care, counseling, housing, and staff and faculty training, these students continue to face institutional barriers that limit their inclusion on campus. 

As a result of these findings, recommendations are aimed at improving the culture and climate of women's colleges for all transgender students. Presented both verbatim from students as well as theorized in conversation with educational policy literature, this study recommends moving beyond inclusion policy as a best practice and to center students within the development and practice of inclusion on campus. The proposed interventions, if adopted by institutions and individuals, will not negate the history and tradition of these colleges, but careful attention to the institutional factors and resources addressed in this dissertation could improve the overall experience for many transgender students.
